Modification_Detail.description: Updated schema version. Adding missing "investigation" references.

Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID Changed LIDs from urn:nasa:pds: to urn:esa:psa: And per "Guide toPDS4 Context Products" v1.7, changed all lidvid_reference to lid_reference

Marsden, R.G., T.R. Sanderson, A.M. Heras, and K.-P. Wenzel, Ulysses SEP Composition Measurements: First Results from the COSPIN LET Experiment, Proc. 22nd Int. Cosmic Ray Conf. (Dublin), 3, 335, 1991.

Simpson, J.A., J.D. Anglin, A. Balogh, M. Bercovitch, J.M. Bouman, E.E. Budzinski, J.R. Burrows, R. Carvell, J.J. Connell, R. Ducros, P. Ferrando, J. Firth, M. Garcia-Munoz, J. Henrion, R.J. Hynds, B. Iwers, R. Jacquet, H. Kunow, G. Lentz, R.G. Marsden, R.B. McKibben, R. Mueller-Mellin, D.E. Page, M. Perkins, A. Raviart, T.R. Sanderson, H. Sierks, L. Treguer, A.J. Tuzzolino, K.-P. Wenzel, and G. Wibberenz, The Ulysses cosmic ray and solar particle investigation, Astron. Astrophys. Suppl. Set: 92, 365-399, 1992.

Instrument.name: COSPIN-High Energy Telescope (HET) for ULY
Instrument.description: The High Energy Telescope (HET) is a sophisticated cosmic ray detection instrument developed as part of the SIM2 project, integrating advanced analogue and digital electronics to perform precise measurements of cosmic rays. Utilizing a dual methodology of particle trajectory determination and the dE/dX versus residual energy technique, the HET characterizes cosmic rays in the energy range from approximately 10 MeV/nucleon to a few hundred MeV/nucleon. This instrument comprises position-sensitive silicon detectors, facilitating the identification of the mass and charge of cosmic particles up to nickel (Z=28), thereby contributing vital data relevant to heliospheric and galactic cosmic ray physics. The telescope's scientific objectives include elucidating particle acceleration mechanisms in solar flares, investigating solar modulation, and analyzing the chemical composition of cosmic rays from supernova nucleosynthesis. The HETâ€™s detector system, featuring multi-strip silicon detectors and robust electronics, ensures high-resolution trajectory mapping and energy assessment, crucial for understanding cosmic ray propagation and interactions. Calibration procedures, including in-flight checks and responses to radiative backgrounds from radioactive thermal generators (RTGs), ensure data integrity and system reliability throughout the mission. By recording event data through a prioritized sampling system, the HET aims to maximize scientific return, enriching our understanding of cosmic phenomena and interstellar environments.
